data.text: Shoes: A Pair for Cycling and a Pair for Hiking?

Question about riding shoes. I get the idea of the stiff sole of a riding shoe and that it allows more energy to the peddle. However, if you also want to do some hiking while on your journey a bike shoe really isn‚Äôt the best for that. So, how many of you carry an extra pair of shoes? A pair for cycling and a pair for hiking? (Besides camp side crocs or flip flops) Or do you use hiking shoes for both purposes? Thanks!

Teva hurricane sandals for cycling and hiking. Pair of flip flops for beach and camping. It would need to be colder than 6-8¬∞C for me to bother with shoes so I just wear thick socks with the sandals. Bonus that it's a great look too
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: I also bring Teva‚Äôs as my only footwear. Let‚Äôs your feet breathe all day and hiking in them is just fine
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text:

data.text: have been using Diagnol straps for years. My first pair were RESTRAP then I made my 2nd set using car seat belts
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: Personally I gone away from SPD Pedals and only use Flat Pedals Shimano XT sometimes with straps,not need to carry walking/hiking shoes + two more things that can not brake.... but I'm not on a fast bike, bike packing on a Surly Ogre.....before I always used SPD, but glad I got over it....
data.author: Thore Burapa Pedersen

data.text: agree, unless your on something like a round the world speed record then what's the hurry
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: Reading this comment üòÄ

data.text:
Normal sandals with hard sole and pretty thick straps I am a fan of Keen and Teva I've written a blog post some time ago, it's in Polish and automatic translation not perfect but understandable https://www.ewcyna.com/en/sandaly-do-turystyki-rowerowej-w-poszukiwaniu-buta-idealnego/

data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Likewise, I ditched my SPD shoes on a tour and just used my Merrells. I keep stopping to take pics and stuff anyway so it wasn't really working out. Unless you feel the need for speed I really wouldn't bother.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: 1 pair of lightweight trail shoes and crocs.
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: What jesus would have done...spd sandals are ace
data.author: Ben Williams

data.text: I use flat MTB pedals and Specialized MTB shoes. They're canvas so look fine for going about town, but are also super grippy to get extra power.
data.author: Victoria James

data.text: Flat pedals and good quality sandals. I was using my 5ten shoes but they're quite hot on the feet in warm weather.
data.author: Richard Ham

data.text: On my first bicycle tour, I wore SPD shoes on the bike and carried casual shoes for off-bike walking plus a pair of Crocs. Yes, correct. Too much luggage, resulting in slow progress on any incline. Changed to flat pedals (Shimano GR500), and wore my very comfortable casuals while riding the bike. Also carried the Crocs, as they are very light, easy to carry and very useful. I won't go back to SPDs.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: If the ride is about cycling only then the choice is ‚Äúclipless‚Äù if if you do other stuff in between cycling then comfortable shoes for the place and the weather and the other non cycling activities and platform pedals
data.author: Tom Heutte

data.text: SPD‚Äùs for gravel/road riding. 5.10‚Äôs for bike packing
data.author: Shaun Marshall

data.text: I second that comment. These help as well as 5/10‚Äôs as you can keep the pedals on for whatever route you‚Äôre riding!
data.author: Mick Krol

data.text: Unless you are doing fast lightweight road touring only I would recommend flat pedals (I prefer mtb style with the pins) with whatever flat shoes suit the weather, including sandles as others have said.
data.author: Brendan Payne

data.text: Depends on the ride .. but mostly ride with SPD, taking either sandals or shoes for a short hikes
data.author: Ray D. Chaplin

data.text: I have used spd's on the bike and brought merrell vapor gloves (extremely lightweight barefoot trainers) in the past. The leather ones even look OK around town. I do like being clipped in over long distances though and it's great to have a dry pair of shoes.
data.author: Jon Belt

data.text: I am pretty much moving over to trail runners for everything now. Around the house, going to the shops, riding the bike, etc. I don't even mean the fancy brand stuff either. On the bike I have large flat pedals, with the grip studs in them. They provide lots of support and having a bit of flex in the shoe suits me. Then I just carry some camp shoes/flipflops or crocs.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Hiking shoes are unnecessary hot and bulky to pedal with. I pack sandals and whatever lightweight shoes I happen to have at the time.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: Last year I used hiking shoes only, but for me it was not comfortable enough. Though I just got a pair of cycle shoes from VAUDE, which is good for cycling as well as walking. By cycle packing I love to ride as light as possible.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: I still use SPD compatable pedals. I wear semi stiff shoes and carry another pair for off the bike. Since the SPD cleat is recessed into the shoe walking is no problem. Since there can be a failure on the STP binding and there are times I want to ride without clipping in I use a one sided clipless pedal. I use the Funn Mamba S. It‚Äôs slightly smaller than the Mamba. To me it offers the best of both worlds.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: Mountain bike shoes. Crocs
data.author: Peter Weldon

data.text:
I‚Äôm a huge fan of the Addidas Five Ten with SPD cleats. The cleats are recessed so it makes them great for off bike activity. They make them without cleats as well. https://www.mbr.co.uk/buyers_guide/five-ten-mountain-bike-shoes-369750
Which Adidas Five Ten mountain bike shoes are right for you? - MBR
mbr.co.uk
data.author: Kelly Lane

data.text: Since there is generally a good chance that I may walk/hike in the course of a ride, I use Merrell Yokota II hikers. They are comfortable and have held up well. When my current pair die, I'll likely purchase another pair.
data.author: Terry L. Manuel

data.text: The stiff sole is important for comfort, or rather to avoid foot pain. I used a toe cap on my pedals and so only one pair of shoes was necessary.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: I ride mountiainbiking shoes with spd and bring and extra lightweigh pair of shoe for walking‚Ä¶ biking on straights and 6-7 hours a day is just nicer with a stiff soleü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
data.author: Anne Bryn

data.text: I ride flat pedals with flat pedal shoes. They work great for shorter hikes- But I wouldn‚Äôt hike 20 miles in them. After riding 50-70 miles a day while touring, I am hard pressed to hike 5.
data.author: Susan Kopczynski Jostrom

data.text:
I carry a pair of Suacony A9‚Äòs with me. They‚Äôre not ‚Äúhiking‚Äù shoes but I don‚Äôt do any serious hiking while on bike tour. They‚Äôre lightweight and extremtly comfortable after a long day though. https://www.amazon.com/Saucony-Mens-Type-Citron-Orange/dp/B07MGJSS9S/ref=asc_df_B07MGJSS9S/?tag=&linkCode=df0&hvadid=393938442186&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=17301030237080333170&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9028779&hvtargid=pla-834831640745&ref=&adgrpid=80492426823&th=1&psc=1

data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Good quality hiking boots like Keens. Dual purpose.
data.author: Jimmy Koyote

data.text: Hiking sneakers is my compromise.
data.author: Jane E. McMaster Snyder

data.text: I wear running shoes so that I can hike and ride.
data.author: Mary Ervin Pinizzotto

data.text: Ditched the clipless shoes and pedals years ago. Keen sandals with a quarter toe clip (no strap) on a platform pedal for cycling. Keens are perfect for walking, and are quite sturdy. Light weight rubber sandals for shower and campsite time. NO bit between the toes, to make them easier to wear with socks on cool evenings.
data.author: Noreen May Light
Noreen May Light
Noreen May Light

data.text: Example of a quarter clip similar to mine. Keeps your foot from accidentally slipping forward off the pedal.
data.author: Noreen May Light

data.text: These Keens have a solid sole, a wide toe "box" area, and wear very well. They adjust at the ankle with Velcro.
data.author: Noreen May Light

data.text: Crocs. Nothing more
data.author: Dan Noble

data.text: I like to be able to change shoes when I rest. Let the cycling ones air out a rad.
data.author: Bruce Richards

data.text: I use spd mtb shoes to cycle(because of a knee injury, my knee stays in a good position that way) and i have walking shoes and flipflops in my bag. Love it this way
data.author: Jonas Lepercq

data.text: I use sturdy leather shoes for both, with a side helping of sandals cos otherwise I get sick to death of being in the same shoes all the time.
data.author: Sarah Wooller

data.text: Depending on the time of year I use Keena sandals or Goretex trailrunners.
data.author: Mariska Baaij

data.text: For extended trips I abandon spds for hiking shoes and toe clips & straps. That way i just have one type of general purpose shoe. Pick some with relatively flat soles...
data.author: Nick Perkins

data.text: I have always worn bike shoes and carried running shoes and sandals.
data.author: Victor Selenow

data.text: Some MTB shoes work okay for shorter hikes; but now you also have to carry a good lock while you‚Äôre away from the bike
data.author: Daniel Gatadero

data.text: Fizik Ergolace X2 & Crank Bros Double Shot pedals - all the options in one set up
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Probably depends in part on the distance you want to ride, and at what intensity. If very relaxed and going short distances - 2 or 3 hours per days cycling - then larger pedals and hiking shoes are probably OK. My wife and I use clip in pedals and shoes as we travel further distances at higher intensity, and like both the stability of being clipped in, and that we can apply power through the entire pedal stroke. Thus, we also each carry a pair of running / walking shoes. Total weight of the 2 x pairs of extra shoes is 1.4kg. It's worth it for us.
data.author: Justin Scholz

data.text: Been touring for almost 5 years continuously. Myself and other long term tourers I met all ride with sandals. Those cycling shoes won't make much of a difference when you are pedaling everyday to different destinations at different distances - some short some long. They will only piss you off. They get hot, stinky (how many socks will you carry? Hand washing them every few days is a PITA and when you go without showers for a few days, clean or dirty socks both stink the same after an hour in the shoes), uncomfortable (being in them 10-14hrs a day is a pita when you will only do 4-6hra of ride time, the rest will be walked in these tight uncomfortable narrow shoes), bulky for storing, and are worthless in mud. They take forever to clean all that thick hard sticky clay mud off, especially in the hard to reach places of the shoe clips. You could carry running shoes with you but you'll soon realize you rarely use them and they just take up space. I put shoe rain covers on my sandals when it's cold and rainy. If it's just cold, I will put on socks - and I don't care if I look like an American or German tourists :) For hiking etc. companies like Keen or Teva make good comfy strong grippy sandals. You'll find its mostly just Americans that buy those big bulky tall hiking boots because marketing tells you too - rest of the world hikes with whatever shoes or sandals they find comfortable
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: Think of it in percentages. How much time do you spend hiking? How much time peddling? If you ride with a strapless pedal system, you can buy either mountain biking shoes, which are good for hiking, or touring shoes, which will take you pretty much everywhere. I use touring shoes by Giro.
data.author: Ross Smith

data.text: Chacos. From Alaska to Chile.and for years
data.author: Darin Dunn

data.text: I have chacos with vibram souls. Hike and bike
data.author: Darin Dunn

data.text: Velosamba‚Ä¶. works
data.author: Ulf Domanski

data.text: Mountain bike shoes might work for you?
data.author: John Part

data.text: I've got SPD shoes for the bike and keen hiking sandals for everything else. My pedals are the hybrid type with SPD clip one side and flats on the other. My shoes are the mountain bike type and pretty good for short walks around towns and villages on route. The sandals are good for site seeing trips once base camp is set up. Works for me.
data.author: Patrick Civil

data.text: I had bike shoes and flip flops/Jandels.
data.author: Sharon Rae

data.text: I‚Äôm shocked with these answers. I done long tours in multiple counties with Sidi road shoes and road cleats. Last year I went to mtn shoes and sod cleats. It was ok. I can‚Äôt imagine riding without being attached to the pedals. You all show me there are lots of ways to have fun.
data.author: Curtis Corlew

data.text: I use sportiva low cut hikers for cycling and hiking. Extra shoes are sandals for the shower
data.author: Heather Burles

data.text: I carry an extra pair of shoes, waterproof ones and they're great!
data.author: David Glashan

data.text: I‚Äôve been using adidas ultra boost for both and very satisfied.
data.author: Francesca Cohn

data.text: Flat pedals, and light hiking shoes with a stiffish midsole. I used to clip in, but increasingly I just don't see the point. When I'm touring, I'm there to see an area and enjoy it - not blast through at high speed. My actual travel pace, once you factor in rest stops and photo stops and "let's go for a swim down at that beach" stops and pub stops, works out to about 10km/h over the average day, so I'm not going to gain any meaningful efficiency from SPDs. I'm better off saving the extra weight, and being comfortable.
data.author: Murray Sovereign

data.text: We recently did the NCN7 from Carlisle to Inverness and only took trainers (we did parkrun en route) & a pair of keen sandals. Lived in the Keens, with stunning suntan result!! ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§£ü§£

data.text: I always rode with SPD shoes plus hiking shoes. Then, after riding the hills in Italy I switched to flats and bought Teva Omnium shoes. Awesome for riding, hiking and casual.
data.author: David Sheppard

data.text: Perferct shoes - spezialized flat rime 2 (i think that was the name) Solid stability, good foe short Hiking trips, water repellent up to a bit waterproof. All time Comfort. They are a hybrid defintely but I think they provide everything you need
